Okay, this guy Thomas Kaplan owns some Rembrandts.
"We've been lending to about 40 museums around the world," Thomas Kaplan tells Post Magazine.
"We used to do that anonymously, and we liked it that way.
Owning doesn't confer respectability.
We had no desire for the social cachet that would come with being seen as big collectors."
But the couple have decided a low-key approach no longer strikes the right note.
In Shanghai, the city where collectors often live by the motto, "If you got it, flaunt it,"
Kaplan explains that he is taking his paintings around the world to spread the word about his other passions,
saving big cats and using art to promote a sense of cultural openness and shared humanity.
In September, he is in Shanghai to launch the "Laid-in Collection" exhibition at the Long Museum,
where visitors are the first to see 78 of the collection's highlights under one roof.
A smaller selection was unveiled at the Louvre in Paris and Beijing's National Museum of China.
The exhibition will travel to the Louvre Abu Dhabi when it leaves Shanghai in February.
